title: Creating and collecting data
text: We will make sure that we know what data comes when, that we have adequate storage space to deal with it, and that all the responsibilities have been taken care of.

questions.title: What data formats/types will you be using?
questions.text: Have you identified types of data that you will use that are used by others too? Some types of data (e.g. genetic variants in the life sciences) are used by many different projects. For such data, often common standards exist that help to make these data reusable. Are you using such common data formats?

questions.title: Is this a standard data format used by others too?
Does this data format enable sharing and long term archiving?
questions.text: Complicated (binary) file formats tend to change over time, and software may not stay compatible with older versions. Also, some formats hamper long term usability by making use of patents or being hampered by restrictive licensing

questions.title: Will you convert to a file format more suitable for archiving later?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: You may need to reserve time and budget for this

questions.title: Will you be using new types of data?
questions.text: Sometimes the type of data you collect can not be stored in a commonly used data format. In such cases you may need to make your own, keeping interoperability as high as possible.

answers.label: No, all of my data will fit in common formats
Yes, I will need to use custom formats for some of my data

questions.title: Will you need to add fields in your data format to a data type registry?
questions.text: Even if the data format you are using is unique to your project, the discrete data items should be reused or reusable as much as possible. Data type registries can help with that.

answers.label: No, all of my data types are described in a data type registry already
Yes, I will add new types to an existing data type registry
Yes, I will create my own data type registry
I will not be using a data type registry

questions.title: Which data type registries will you use?
Do you need to create vocabularies or ontologies for any of your data items?
questions.text: For good interoperability the use of controlled vocabularies for each discrete data item is advisable. If such vocabularies exist, it is best to reuse those.

answers.label: No, suitable public controlled vocabularies or ontologies exist for all of my data types
Yes, I will make and publish a vocabulary or ontology for some of my data
Not all of my discrete data items will be coming from an ontology or vocabulary

questions.title: How will you design your new data format?

answers.label: There is a closely related more generic and open format that I can specialize
I will use a Linked Data format
I will use a completely custom data format

questions.title: Will you describe your new data format for others?

answers.label: Yes, I will register my standards at a data standards registry

questions.title: How will you be storing metadata?
questions.text: For the re-usability of your data by yourself or others at a later stage, a lot of information about the data, how it was collected and how it can be used should be stored with the data. Such data about the data is called metadata, and this set of questions are about this metadata

questions.title: Do suitable 'Minimal Metadata About ...' (MIA...) standards exist for your experiments?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Did you really check a service like fairsharing.org to verify this?

questions.title: Do you have a good idea of what metadata is needed to make it possible for others to read and interpret your data in the future?
Do you know how and when you will be collecting the necessary metadata?
questions.text: Often it is easiest to make sure you collect the metadata as early as possible.

questions.title: Will you consider re-usability of your data beyond your original purpose?
questions.text: Adding more than the strict minimum metadata about your experiment will possibly allow more wide re-use of your data, with associated higher data citation rates. Please note that it is not easy for yourself to see all other ways in which others could be reusing your data.

answers.label: No, I will just document the bare minimum
Yes, I will document more metadata than needed for reproducibility

questions.title: How will you balance the extra efforts with the potential for added reusability?

answers.label: I will see what I can do
I will use preselected additional standard modules of metadata
I will collect all metadata I can gather and document the data set beyond minimal standards

questions.title: Do you need to exchange your data with others?
Did you consider how to monitor data integrity?
questions.text: Working with large amounts of heterogenous data in a larger research group has implications for the data integrity. How do you make sure every step of the workflow is done with the right version of the data? How do you handle the situation when a mistake is uncovered? Will you be able to redo the strict minimum data handling?

questions.title: Will you be keeping a master list with checksums of certified/correct/canonical/verified data?
questions.text: Data corruption or mistakes can happen with large amounts of files or large files. Keeping a master list with data checksums can be helpful to prevent expensive mistakes. It can also be helpful to keep the sample list under version control forcing that all changes are well documented.

questions.title: Will you define a way to detect file or sample swaps, e.g. by measuring something independently?
Do all datasets you work with have a license?
questions.text: It is not always clear to everyone in the project (ad outside) what can and can not be done with a data set. It is helpful to associate each data set with a license as early as possible in the project. A data license should ideally be as free as possible: any restriction like 'only for non-commercial use' or 'attribution required' may reduce the reusability and thereby the number of citations. If possible, use a computer-readable and computer actionable license.

questions.title: Will you store the licenses with the data at all time?
questions.text: It is very likely that data will be moved and copied. At some point people may lose track of the origins. It can be helpful to have the licenses (of coarse as open as possible) stored in close association with the data.

questions.title: How will you keep provenance?
questions.text: To make your experiments reproducible, all steps in the data processing must be documented in detail. The software you used, including version number, all options and parameters. This information together for every step of the analysis is part of the so-called data provenance. There are more questions regarding this in the chapter on data processing and curation.

answers.label: All steps will be documented in an (electronic) lab notebook
Our work flow system documents the provenance automatically and completely

references.description: Keeping a log of every step in the analysis workflow that has been run

questions.title: How will you do file naming and file organization?
questions.text: Putting some thoughts into file naming can save a lot of trouble later.

questions.title: Did you make a SOP (Standard Operating Procedure) for file naming?
questions.text: It can help if everyone in the project uses the same naming scheme.

questions.title: Describe your SOP (Standard Operating Procedure) for file naming
questions.text: Describe how everyone in the project will be naming files and folders, and what folder structure you will use

questions.title: Will you be keeping the relationships between data clear in the file names?
questions.text: Advice: Use the same identifiers for sample IDs etc throughout the entire project.

questions.title: Will all the metadata in the file names also be available in the proper metadata?
questions.text: The file names are very useful as metadata for people involved in the project, but to computers they are just identifiers. To prevent accidents with e.g. renamed files metadata information should always also be available elsewhere and not only through the file name.

answers.label: No, the file names in the project are an essential part of the metadata
Yes, all metadata is also explicitly available elsewhere

questions.title: Please specify what data sets you will acquire using measurement equipment
questions.text: You can use any name for the data set, make sure that it identifies the data set to yourself

questions.title: Who will do the measurements? And where?
questions.text: Are there easily accessible specialized service providers for data capture?

answers.label: Experts in the project, with our own equipment
Experts in the project, at a specialized infrastructure
External party
answers.advice: consider making them partner in the project

questions.title: Has formal ownership of the data been established?

answers.label: The party measuring the data owns it
The project partners acquire full ownership

questions.title: What other arrangements?
Has responsibility for long term safe keeping of the raw data been established? Who will deal with data publication?

answers.label: The measuring party will publish it after a fixed embargo period
The measuring party will publish it when the project tells them to
The measuring party will delete the data, the project partners will deal with data publication

questions.title: What other arrangements?
Is the equipment completely standard and well described?
questions.text: If the technology is very much under development, you may want to come back later to understand exactly how the measurements have been made. Is the measurement equipment and protocol sufficiently standard that you will be able to explain how it is done or refer to a standard explanation?

answers.label: Less well described or not completely standard
answers.advice: Take pictures of the instruments for documentation, and keep copies of any documentation.

questions.title: Is special care needed to get the raw data ready for processing?
questions.text: Where does the data come from? And who will need it? Sometimes the raw data is measured somewhere else than where the primary processing is taking place. In such cases the ingestion or transport of the primary data may take special planning. You also need to make sure that data is secure and that data integrity is guaranteed.

questions.title: Is the data format established?
questions.text: Has the storage and transport format of the primary data been established between the people responsible for the measurement and the people responsible for the processing?

questions.title: How will the raw data be transported?

answers.label: No transport is needed, analysis is done where it is obtained

questions.title: Is sufficient writing and reading capacity available for the physical media?
questions.text: Has time been reserved on any tape/disk reading and writing stations?

answers.label: Yes, has been taken care of

questions.title: Is sufficient network capacity available?
questions.text: Can the volume of data be accommodated by the standard network connection? Has a special network connection (e.g. light path) that is needed been reserved?

answers.label: Yes, has been taken care of

questions.title: Is data integrity guaranteed during this stage?
questions.text: Do you have any means of identifying whether the raw data has been transferred error free and has not been tampered with?

questions.title: Is data security guaranteed during this stage?
questions.text: Are the raw data encrypted or otherwise protected from theft or leaks at either site or during transport? You could e.g. use a light path or a virtual private network if you transport the data over the net.

questions.title: Do you have any non-equipment data capture?
questions.text: Does the data you collect contain non-equipment captured data such as questionnaires, case report forms, electronic patient records?

questions.title: Will you be collecting questionnaires?
Will you be collecting case report forms?
Will you be collecting data from electronic patient records?
Has access to the electronic patient records been arranged?
Please list all non-equipment data sets you will collect
questions.text: You can use any name for the data set, make sure that it identifies the data set to yourself

questions.title: How will the data be captured?

answers.label: Data will first be on paper

questions.title: Who will do the data entry?

answers.label: One of the members of the project team

questions.title: What other arrangements?
Did you arrange who will make the data digitally available to you?
Will all data be collected by a single person?

answers.label: This data will be collected by one person

questions.title: Is there a risk of different interpretations? Subjectivity?

answers.label: There are internal controls to deal with interperation differences
We accept the risk of different interpretations

questions.title: What other arrangements?
Is there a data integration tool that can handle and combine all the data types you are dealing with in your project?
Can all data be brought into the same format, e.g. RDF?
What software will you be using to collect all data?

answers.label: We will not use a data warehouse

questions.title: Why will you develop your own software?

answers.label: Nothing like this has ever been done before
Existing solutions are not suitable
answers.advice: Did you consider collaborating to improve an existing solution?

questions.title: Will you be storing samples?
